Graphical abstract The main research directions of SECM applied to understand electrocatalytic reactions in energy conversion and storage systems are reviewed. To address climate change and promote environmental sustainability, electrochemical energy conversion and storage systems emerge as promising alternative to fossil fuels, catering to the escalating demand for energy. Achieving optimal energy efficiency and cost competitiveness in these systems requires the strategic design of electrocatalysts, coupled with a thorough comprehension of the underlying mechanisms and degradation behavior occurring during the electrocatalysis processes. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), an analytical technique for studying surface electrochemically, stands out as a powerful tool offering electrochemical insights. It possesses remarkable spatiotemporal resolution, enabling the visualization of the localized electrochemical activity and surface topography. This review compiles crucial research findings and recent breakthroughs in electrocatalytic processes utilizing the SECM methodology, specifically focusing on applications in electrolysis, fuel cells, and metal–oxygen batteries within the realm of energy conversion and storage systems. Commencing with an overview of each energy system, the review introduces the fundamental principles of SECM, and aiming to provide new perspectives and broadening the scope of applied research by describing the major research categories within SECM. Keywords Scanning electrochemical microscopy Electrocatalyst Electrocatalysis Water splitting Fuel cell Metal-oxygen battery 1 Introduction With the increasing energy demands, energy conversion and energy storage systems, such as water-splitting devices, fuel cells, and metal-oxygen batteries (MOBs), have been widely considered as promising alternatives to fossil fuels and enable sustainable energy [1–7]. Electrochemical reactions involving oxygen and hydrogen, such as the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), constitute the core of green energy systems [8–10]. During these reactions, the electrocatalysts play a crucial role in minimizing the overpotentials and accelerating the reaction rate [11–13]. Consequently, achieving a comprehensive understanding of heterogeneous electrocatalytic reactions and rationally designing electrocatalysts are essential for enhancing overall energy efficiency and cost competitiveness in various systems. Various characterization techniques, including scanning electron microscopy-energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (SEM-EDS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV-vis fluorescence microscopy, and Raman spectroscopy, have been employed to analyze the chemical and structural properties of electrocatalysts [14]. By supplementing the electrochemical techniques, these methods contribute to study electrocatalyst performance and structure-activity relationships [15–19]. Traditional electrochemical results, based on the assumption of uniform reactions, often provide average information [20]. However, electrocatalytic reactions at the electrode-electrolyte interface are spatially heterogeneous due to the surface structural influences from defects, crystallography, and the material composition for hierarchical catalyst design [21–25]. In addition, this could lead to differences in the reaction rate depending on the location or possibly accelerate irreversible catalytic reactions over time [26–29]. Hence, investigating electrochemical activity with high spatiotemporal resolution is vital to attain an in-depth understanding of the electrocatalysis mechanism and degradation process. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), a surface analysis technique, provides detailed information about the electrochemical reactions in the actual electrolyte environment by evaluating the ultramicroelectrode (UME) tip currents as a function of tip position over a substrate [30–33]. Therefore, owing to the inherent benefit of high lateral resolution offered by UME, SECM allows for efficient mapping of localized catalytically active interfaces and surface topographic properties [34–38]. Furthermore, quantitative real-time analysis based on SECM enables the observation of reaction intermediates, reaction sites, and kinetic parameters, contributing to the understanding the catalytic reaction mechanisms and material degradation behavior [39–42]. As SECM is a specialized technique for the investigation of high-resolution electrochemical properties at the nanoscale, it has applications in a variety of fields. Notably, the number of publications related to SECM has steadily increased in recent years (Fig. 1 ). Corrosion analysis and bioelectrochemistry research are relevant to this trend. In particular, there has been a notable surge in the use of SECM, with expansion of its applications, such as water electrolysis, fuel cells, batteries, and various energy storage and conversion systems. Despite the growing applications of SECM, challenges persist in ensuring reliable measurement and clear interpretation, especially for complex electrochemical reactions in energy conversion and storage systems. Addressing issues related to surface-blocking gases and the measurement environment for highly reactive materials, such as lithium, requires further attention [43–46]. Nevertheless, ongoing efforts in technological advancements based on SECM methodology consistently provide meaningful insights and improvements in electrochemical energy conversion and storage systems. This review primarily focuses on the SECM methodology for analyzing electrocatalytic reactions within energy conversion and storage systems, specifically in electrolysis, fuel cells, and MOBs— fields predominantly characterized by electrocatalytic reactions. The goal of this review is to maximize the utility of SECM in understanding the intricate electrocatalytic reactions within these systems. The review aims to guide the selection of suitable SECM modes based on the desired outcomes achievable through SECM methodology and offer guidelines on adjusting factors (such as applied potential, mediators, potential range, etc.) for effective SECM measurements. Research in this field is broadly categorized into six main directions: electrochemical imaging analysis, material screening, investigation of gas behavior, validation of electrochemical mechanism, evaluation of rate constants for kinetics, and integrated analysis with other evaluation methods (Fig. 2 ). By systematically exploring SECM's practical application in energy conversion and storage, this review will elevate understanding of electrocatalytic reaction, offering new insights and expanding the scope of applied research using SECM. 2 Principle of energy catalysis in energy conversion/storage system 2.1 Catalytic reactions in electrolytic cell and fuel cell Research in energy conversion systems is primarily focused on electrolysis and fuel cells [47]. Catalysts play a crucial role in facilitating electrocatalytic reactions within these research areas, aiding in the breaking and forming chemical bonds within water molecules. The OER exhibits distinct characteristics in acidic and alkaline environments. In acidic conditions, efficient electrical energy conversion at low overpotential is possible, and universal metal oxide catalysts exhibit high activity, enabling efficient oxygen generation. On the other hand, under alkaline conditions, internal electrical resistance is lowered due to the abundance OH− ion in the electrolyte, improving electrochemical efficiency, and specific catalysts may exhibit higher oxygen generation rates [48]. However, alkaline conditions require high overpotential and may be detrimental to the catalyst. Under acidic conditions, high acidity increases the internal electrical resistance of the electrolyte and can corrode the catalyst, resulting in unsatisfactory electrochemical efficiency and stability. Various efforts are being made to overcome these challenges. Research is underway to improve the reactivity and stability of catalysts in each environment by controlling catalyst composition, surface properties, and selection of support materials in both acidic and alkaline environments [49]. Based on these considerations, further research is needed to comprehend the reaction mechanisms. To delve into the mechanisms of these reactions, various approaches utilizing SECM have been reported. This technique proves invaluable in unraveling the complexities of electrochemical processes, providing insights into reaction mechanisms and kinetics. Hence, this section aims to elucidate the fundamental principles of this research field, highlighting how SECM serves as a pivotal tool for evaluating and analyzing reactions within the context of electrocatalysis and fuel cells. This understanding is crucial for effectively describing and optimizing electrocatalytic reactions in these systems. 2.1.1 Electrolytic cells The electrolytic cell employs a water-splitting process, converting electrical energy into chemical energy by decomposing water into hydrogen and oxygen (Fig. 3 a). The efficiency of water electrolysis depends on the pH of the electrolyte, which fundamentally governs the entire reaction mechanism. Under acidic conditions, water is oxidized at the anode, resulting in an OER, as described in Eq. (1). Simultaneously, at the cathode, a reduction reaction of hydrogen ions occurs yielding a HER, as described in Eq. (2). (1) 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 4 e - + 4 H + (2) 4 H + + 4 e - → 2 H 2 The water-splitting reaction in acidic media promotes efficient energy consumption and accelerates hydrogen production [50]. However, due to the low pH environment, the catalyst materials are limited to noble metals and their oxides, which exhibit sufficient robustness in the electrolyte but increase the cost of cell fabrication [51]. In contrast, under alkaline conditions, hydroxide ions release electrons at the anode to generate oxygen and water, as demonstrated in Eq. (3). Simultaneously, water is reduced at the cathode, initiating the HER and producing hydrogen and hydroxide ions as shown in Eq. (4). (3) 4 O H - → O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - (4) 4 H 2 O + 4 e - → 2 H 2 + 4 O H - Due to the high pH level in the alkaline environment, it is crucial to lower the energy barrier for the water dissociation step, and the electrode surface is mainly used for reaction with high corrosion resistance [52]. To date, much research has focused on developing catalyst materials that exhibit better catalytic performance under alkaline conditions, which can expand the material selection range [53–57]. 2.1.2 Fuel cells In contrast to electrolytic cells, fuel cells operate by converting chemical energy into electrical energy through the external supply of oxygen and hydrogen (Fig. 3b). Under acidic conditions, the supplied hydrogen is oxidized into the hydrogen ions, generating electrical power through the HOR, as demonstrated in Eq. (5). The generated electrons move to the cathode through an external circuit, while the hydrogen ions migrate to the cathode through the electrolyte. Simultaneously, the oxygen supplied to the cathode undergoes an ORR with transferred hydrogen ions and electrons to produce water as described in Eq. (6). (5) 2 H 2 → 4 H + + 4 e - (6) O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - → 2 H 2 O In an acidic electrolyte environment, the materials with high ionic conductivity, such as a proton exchange membrane (PEM) or a polymer electrolyte for batteries, excel in facilitating the movement of hydrogen ions. This characteristic accelerates the operating speed and enables the attainment of elevated power densities [58]. Conversely, under alkaline conditions, the hydrogen supplied to the anode generates water and electrons through the HOR with hydroxide ions. In contrast to acidic condition, hydroxide ions migrate in alkaline electrolytes. The externally supplied oxygen on the cathode undergoes the ORR with water, yielding hydroxide ions, as shown in Eq. (8). (7) 2 H 2 + 4 O H - → 4 H 2 O + 4 e - (8) O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - → 4 O H - Instead of expensive precious metals, cost-effective metals such as corrosion-resistant nickel can be used as electrode materials in alkaline electrolytes. Furthermore, through appropriate alloy configurations, these metals can deliver performance comparable to platinum. Consequently, this approach mitigates the overall cost of fuel cells [59]. Fuel cell technology holds significant potential as a clean energy source, but there are several technical, economic, and environmental challenges that must be addressed. Therefore, continuous research and innovation are crucial for the effective development and expansion of fuel cell technology. 2.2 Catalytic reaction in metal-oxygen batteries With the growing demand for high-energy–density batteries, the exploration of alternatives to lithium-ion batteries has become imperative. MOBs, which utilize lightweight oxygen gas as the cathode's active material, hold the theoretical promise of remarkably enhanced energy density. MOBs operate by chemical reacting oxygen from the atmosphere with metal ions to generate energy. Understanding the behavior of oxygen, the catalytic activity during the formation and decomposition of discharge products, and analyzing the kinetics of redox mediators utilized as liquid catalysts are essential in MOBs. Oxygen batteries address their challenges through innovative approaches, including the incorporating of redox mediators [60,61]. The SECM emerges as a powerful and effective tool for analysis, providing three-dimensional spatial resolution not only on the electrode's surface but also within the electrolyte. Before delving into the application of SECM in MOB analysis, it is crucial to explore the principles of MOBs. The LOBs, most representative type of MOBs, consist of four main components: a metallic lithium anode; a gas diffusion electrode (GDE) supplying active O2 species; and an aprotic electrolyte and separator (Fig. 3c and d). The ideal operation of LOBs is based on the reversible electrochemical formation and decomposition of lithium peroxide (Li2O2) during discharging and recharging, respectively. During discharge, a three-phase reaction involving the solid (GDE), liquid (Li+ in electrolyte), and gas (oxygen) contributes to the ORR, resulting in the formation of the discharge product Li2O2 on the positive electrode (Fig. 3c). In contrast, Li2O2 is reversely decomposed through the OER during the recharging process, following Eq. (9) (Fig. 3d). (9) 2 L i + s o l + O 2 g + 2 e - ⇄ L i 2 O 2 ( s ) Other types of MOBs, such as sodium-oxygen batteries (NaOBs), magnesium-oxygen batteries (MgOBs), and zinc-oxygen batteries (ZOBs), share similar challenges. The MOBs based on magnesium and zinc, following Eq. (10). (10) M 2 + s o l + O 2 g + 2 e - ⇄ 2 M O ( s ) Due to the insulating nature and large band gap of Li2O2 [62–64], the reverse decomposition reaction does not occur efficiently. Therefore, Li2O2 accumulates during repeated cycling, causing pore blockage [65–67] or the formation of a passivation layer [68–70] on the metallic lithium surface. This accumulation results in high charge overpotential, poor cyclability, and sudden failure of cells. To reduce the high charge overpotential and increase the reversibility of the Li2O2 decomposition reaction, various studies on solid-based catalysts capable of promoting the OER or ORR process have been reported [71–73]. However, it has been reported that solid-based catalysts induce non-selective catalytic effects, leading to the decomposition of battery components such as Li2O2 and the electrolyte, resulting in cell failure [74]. Furthermore, solid-based catalysts have the limitation that their catalytic activity depends on contact with Li2O2. Consequently, decomposition of Li2O2 detached from the positive electrode or not in contact with the catalyst proves challenging, resulting in incomplete Li2O2 decomposition. To address the nonselective catalytic effect and deactivation of the catalyst, a solution has been proposed the use of a mobile liquid catalyst called a redox mediator (RM) [75]. Whereas solid-based catalyst loaded onto the positive electrode, the RM is a soluble catalyst that is homogeneously dispersed within the electrolyte. At the redox potential of the RM, it undergoes oxidation before the electrochemical reaction of Li2O2 (Eq. (11)). Subsequently, the RM+ undergoes a rapid charge-transfer reaction upon contact with Li2O2, leading to its chemical decomposition (Eq. (12)). The RM effectively lowers its charge potential to match, facilitating the clear decomposition of even detached Li2O2 from the positive electrode. Consequently, the RM improves the rechargeability and cyclability of the LOBs [76–79]. Other types of MOBs, such as NaOBs, MgOBs, and ZOBs, share similar challenges. The MOBs based on magnesium and zinc, follow Eq. (10). (11) 2 R M s o l ⇄ 2 R M + ( s o l ) + 2 e - (12) L i 2 O 2 s + 2 R M + sol ⇄ 2 L i + sol + O 2 g + 2 R M ( sol ) 3 Principle of SECM 3.1 Principle and operation mode for SECM SECM, a scanning probe microscopy technique utilizing UMEs, acquire electrochemical information and microtopographical properties on the sample surface in an electrolyte. In 1986, Engstrom et al. pioneered the exploration of SECM, employing UMEs to determine surface activity with the concept of electrochemical diffusion layers [80]. Subsequently, Bard et al. advanced SECM in 1989, contributing to improved performance, enhanced resolution, optimized experimental conditions, and increased sensitivity [81]. Comprising four electrodes (the tip, counter electrode, reference electrode, and substrate) and equipped with a bipotentiostat for independent control of the UME and substrate potentials, SECM offers precise spatial control. The positioning of the UME is finely tuned using a high-resolution XYZ stage and a piezo controller. The spatial resolution, a pivotal factor in SECM imaging analysis, is affected by the tip-to-substrate distance (d) and tip diameter ( r T ) [82]. SECM is an analytic technique based on diffusion principles for studying electrochemical processes on surfaces in a liquid environment, with hemispherical diffusion occurring around the tip of the UME [83]. Compared to the linear diffusion observed at conventional electrodes, the hemispherical diffusion of UMEs allows significantly faster mass transport, allowing for the measurement of diffusion-limited current densities [84]. The reduced tip sizes of UMEs provide high sensitivity in electrochemical analysis by minimizing resistance drop, capacitive current, and promoting mass transfer during measurement. When the UME reaches steady state in the bulk solution, the current can be expressed by the following Eq. (13) derived from Fick's law [80,85]. (13) i T , ∞ = 4 n F D 0 C R ∗ r T where n is the number of electrons transferred, F is the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol−1), D 0 is the diffusion coefficient, C R ∗ is the concentration of reactant species in the bulk solution, and r T is the radius of the UME. SECM offers various operation modes depending on the purpose of the analysis, including feedback, generator-collector, surface interrogation, redox competition, and scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECCM) modes, as summarized in Fig. 4 . 3.2 Feedback mode In feedback (FB) mode, a potential is applied to the UME as a probe for measuring the feedback current generated by the redox mediator [86]. The aspects of this feedback current were influenced by the electron-transfer rate of the electroactive species by the substrate [81]. In the bulk solution, the reversible redox mediator species, denoted as the reduced species ‘R’, can undergo oxidation, transforming into the oxidized species ‘O’ by exposure to the polarized UME. This process is further studied using Eq. (14). (14) R → O + n e - When the tip is positioned far from the substrate, the steady-state-diffusion-limited current, i T , ∞ , is determined due to hemispherical diffusion, as described in Eq. (13). When the UME approaches the insulating substrate, the recorded current at the tip ( i T ) decreases ( i T < i T , ∞ ), referred to as negative feedback (Fig. 4a). This decrease in current is result of the hindered diffusion of redox mediators to the tip electrode surface. On the other hand, when the UME approaches the conductive or electrochemically active substrate, the substrate surface can reduce the previously formed oxidation species ‘O’ at the UME back to ‘R’. This leads to an increase in the tip current ( i T ), surpassing the current in the bulk solution despite the diffusional hindrance ( i T > i T , ∞ ), which called positive feedback (Fig. 4b). The feedback responses on the conductive substrate are determined by an interplay of diffusion hindrance and electron-transfer rate. A higher electron-transfer rate between the conductive substrate and the redox mediator tends to exhibit closer to positive feedback [87]. 3.3 Generation/collection mode The generation/collection (G/C) modes are categorized into tip generation/substrate collection (TG/SC) and substrate generation/tip collection (SG/TC) modes. In the SG/TC mode, redox species generated from the substrate diffuse to the tip and undergo an electrochemical reaction to detect the collecting signal. Unlike the feedback mode, where the redox mediator is present in the solution, resulting in a faradaic background current at the tip ( i T , ∞ ), the G/C mode generally excludes the redox mediator from the electrolyte. Instead, it is generated either at the tip or at the substrate. For the TG/SC mode, applying the appropriate potential to the tip induces the reduction of O at the tip, leading to the generation of R, which diffuses to the substrate and can be subsequently oxidized back to O. In contrast, in the SG/TC mode, R is produced from the substrate and captured by the tip (Fig. 4c). The sample current measured in the G/C mode provides information about the local electrochemical activity of the sample [88–91]. Especially, in SG/TC mode, it is important to minimize the distance between the tip and substrate to enhance the collection efficiency of electrochemical signals, diminished by the difference in size between the substrate and electrode [92,93]. 3.4 Redox competition mode Redox competition (RC) mode is the principle that allows both the tip and substrate to engage simultaneously in identical redox reactions, competing for the same electroactive species within the electrolyte (Fig. 4d) [94]. As the system reaches a steady tip/substrate current state, the measured current remains constant while the tip scans across inactive regions of the substrate. However, at active sites, the observed tip current gradually diminishes. This decrease is attributed to the limited diffusion of R within the bulk, hindering its movement after being consumed by the substrate. The RC mode offers a significant advantage by effectively mitigating interference from background currents, in contrast to the TG/SC mode [95,96]. Additionally, this mode offers valuable insight into reaction rates and can effectively discern between active and inactive regions, making it a valuable tool for studying various electrochemical systems. 3.5 Surface interrogation mode Surface interrogation (SI) mode, unlike other modes, is based on transient measurements and serves to quantify species adsorbed on the substrate surface [97,98]. This mode initiates by applying a potential to the substrate to adsorbed species (A) onto it. Subsequently, the substrate is switched to an open-circuit potential (Fig. 4e). While maintaining the substrate at an open circuit, a potential is applied to the tip, leading to the generation of the R reduced from the O on the tip surface. The R then diffuses between the substrate and tip, reacting with A to regenerate O and transform into the product (P). This process eventually leads to the consumption of A and the generation of species O. The dynamic interaction between the absorbed species on the substrate surface and the tip-generated species establishes a positive feedback loop. If A is entirely consumed, the reaction rate of O at the tip is impeded due to the absence of chemical reactions in the tip-substrate gap, resulting in a negative feedback response from the system. The interaction between positive and negative feedback enables the quantification of the electrode surface state [99–102]. Accurate quantification of adsorbates typically necessitates a substrate of similar size to the UME. When the substrate is much larger than the tip, lateral charge transfer induces electron transfer between the mediator and the substrate, fostering the regeneration of the mediator. Consequently, even in the absence of adsorbates, O regenerated by the substrate increases the current at the tip, distorting the quantification of adsorbates. On the other hand, with an insulating substrate preventing mediator regeneration, the application of SI mode is feasible regardless of the substrate's size. 3.6 Scanning electrochemical cell microscopy Scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECCM) involves creating a meniscus at the bottom of the probe using a micropipette that contains electrolytes, forming a confined electrochemical cell in contact with the surface of interest (Fig. 4f) [103]. Applying a potential between the electrodes induces ion and electron transfer through the meniscus, leading to current modulation and enabling a comprehensive investigation of the inherent electrochemical properties of the sample. Utilizing the hopping mode of the pipette by traversing the surface ensures minimal exposure to the solution, allowing for the measurement of the material properties without the risk of sample contamination or corrosion [104–107]. 4 Application of SECM to study catalytic reactions 4.1 Visualization of catalytic active site Catalysts, even if composed of the same material, can exhibit varying activity levels influenced by parameters like adjacent substances, location, state, composition, and size of catalysts. Manipulating these factors has led to notable enhancements in the performance of electrocatalysts [108–112]. However, conventional analytical methods often offer only averaged activity, making it challenge in precisely assessing the extent of such enhancements. To overcome these limitations, SECM has emerged as a powerful tool, providing exceptional spatial resolution to visualize localized characteristics. This capability allows SECM to offer valuable insights into conditions that maximize catalytic activity. Additionally, SECM utilizes a bipotentiostat to simultaneously apply distinct potentials to the substrate and UME. This feature enables the induction of various catalytic reactions for HER, HOR, OER, and ORR without the need for additional configurations [113,114]. Consequently, SECM provides excellent insight for observing and understanding distribution of activity. This chapter explores the utilization of SECM to visually depict catalytic activity in specific environments, aiding in the comprehension and optimization of enhanced catalytic properties. Wang et al. distinguished the two phases by observing dynamic changes during the phase transition process in mixed MoS2 nanosheets (1T-2H MoS2) through fast scanning measurements in FB and SG/TC modes [115]. The MoS2 nanosheets consist of a metallic 1T phase and a semiconducting 2H phase (Fig. 5 a), with the widely recognized higher catalytic efficiency of the 1T phase [116,117]. However, the 1T phase transforms to the 2H phase due to its thermodynamic instability, and the phase-transition process occurs rapidly even at a very low temperature by a low energy barrier. Because of this rapid transition process, there are numerous challenges in accurate measurement. Utilizing the fast scan mode, a dynamic tracking was performed to distinguish the phase transition process of MoS2 based on the feedback current, reflecting the difference in conductivity between two phases (Fig. 5b). Furthermore, in SG/TC mode, it was observed that the edge of the 2H MoS2 region exhibits higher catalytic activity for the HER (Fig. 5c), and they demonstrated that fast scanning minimizes diffused hydrogen interference. Sun et al. studied complex heterogeneous nickel oxide (NiO) catalysts on highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) substrates to identify local active sites according to their topography [118]. The surface of 2D NiO nanosheets was scanned in FB mode using a ferrocene redox mediator. As the tip moves from HOPG to NiO, the feedback current decreased due to the low-conductive surface of semi-2D NiO, which attenuated the reduction rate of Fc+ more than HOPG. In SG/TC mode, the tip current for NiO increased, indicating a higher oxygen flux than the inert HOPG. In particular, the highest current observed at the edges of 2D-NiO nanocrystals, amplified by 10%–20%, suggested that the OER occurs more prominently on the surface of NiO nanosheets, with the highest catalytic activity observed on the (100) plane corresponding to the NiO edge. Weng et al. conducted an assessment of bimetallic materials (Pt-M, M is Pd, Ru, and Ir) in TG/SC mode to determine the most optimal composition among candidates exhibiting high catalytic activity for the HOR [119]. The mapping results revealed that Pt4Pd6, Pt9Ru1, and Pt3Ir7 catalysts exhibited higher currents compared to other catalysts in the bimetallic system, implying better HOR activity in each composition. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) indicated that when the substrate potential exceeded a specific level, adsorbed oxygen species and surface oxides formed on the catalyst, leading to a rapid drop in tip current. This observation aligns with literature findings suggesting that the formation of a surface oxide layer could hinder the catalytic activity of Pt metal [120]. Additionally, it was confirmed that the current rises again when the substrate potential reaches a certain value, indicating the preservation of the metal properties. In conclusion, TG/SC screening with CV curve effectively identify the appropriate composition of promising bimetallic materials for efficient hydrogen oxidation [121–123]. Takahashi et al. employed high-resolution SECCM to electrochemically map the site-dependent catalytic HER activity of transition-metal dichalcogenide (TMD) nanosheets [124]. CV measurements within the SECCM droplet simultaneously provided the overpotential of 1H-MoS2 on a catalytically inert HOPG substrate (Fig. 5d) and the Tafel slope (Fig. 5e). The active sites in the 1H-MoS2 edge region exhibited enhanced electrochemical HER activity compared to the terrace region, which is evident from a higher current response, lower overpotential (dark-blue-colored region), and lower Tafel slope (dark-yellow-colored region) compared to the terrace region when reaching −1.4 V. Additionally, the aging effect of the catalysts (MoS2 and WS2 heteronanosheets) was electrochemically analyzed by comparing the activity of a newly prepared catalyst with that of a catalyst exposed to air for 11 months. The fresh catalyst displayed higher activity at the edges, whereas the aging sample exhibited lower HER currents due to the oxidation at the edge parts and the absorption of organic contaminants. This study successfully demonstrated the applicability of SECCM for visualizing local catalytic reactions in inhomogeneous materials and understanding their degradation behavior. Wert et al. investigated the changes in morphological and electrochemical properties of transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs, MoS2, TiS2, and TiSe2) during HER to confirm the electrocatalytic stability. TMDs are recognized as promising materials as electrocatalysts [125]. The degree of corrosion decreased in the order of TiSe2 > TiS2 > MoS2, indicating strong stability for the catalytic reaction during short-term utilization. These comparison methods can confirm the decomposition behavior according to the spatial resolution of the material and ultimately identify the factors influencing the stability of the catalytic reaction. Li et al. evaluated the HER performance of 2H-MoS2 in a multilayer structure combined with Bi2Te3 (Fig. 5f) [126]. In the mapping of SG/TC mode, the single MoS2 layer exhibits low HER activity, whereas the tip current increases rapidly at the surface of the MoS2/Bi2Te3 multilayer, indicating enhanced activity (Fig. 5g). Despite the chemically inert basal plane of MoS2 being unfavorable for hydrogen adsorption, the high HER activity in the multilayer suggest that the delocalized sp-derived surface state of Bi2Te3 could donate electrons to the MoS2 layer, thereby increasing the H binding [127]. Therefore, the structure-dependent catalytic activity for the HER was effectively quantified. It was confirmed that the enhanced activity was attributed to charge redistribution at the interface between the Bi2Te3 topological insulator films and the MoS2 layer. Gao et al. visualized the bifunctional catalytic activity for both the HER and OER on the same position in the nickel foam (NF)-based monolithic electrode by changing the applied potential in SG/TC mode (Fig. 5h and i) [128]. The electrode is composed of metallic Ni and Ni/α-Ni(OH)2 complex distributed in the valley and top, respectively. In the HER SECM scan, potentials of 0.7 and −0.65 V vs. Ag/AgCl were applied to the tip and electrode, respectively, inducing hydrogen generation in the electrode and reduction of hydrogen in the tip (schematic in Fig. 5h). The mapping result in Fig. 5(h) indicates a high current (blue-white color) in the valley area where Ni metal is distributed, implying that Ni metal possesses high HER activity with the formation of Ni-Had [129,130]. Conversely, for OER evaluation, −0.65 and 1.2 V were applied to the tip and electrode, respectively, inducing O2 generated in the electrode to be reduced at the tip (schematic in Fig. 5i). The mapping result in Fig. 5(i) shows a high current (red color) in area where Ni/α-Ni(OH)2 is present. This result implies that the hydroxide serves as the site of evolution for the OER and the slightly positively charged Ni(OH)2 readily accepts hydroxide anions, enhancing the kinetics of the OER [131]. In this research, the distribution of the HER and OER evolution sites of the bifunctional electrocatalyst was easily confirmed by controlling the applied potential by SG/TC. Therefore, the utilization of SECM for visualization of the catalytic active sites enables the discrimination of local catalytic activity originating from factors such as grain boundaries, phases, orientations, composition elements, and the multi-layer structure of catalytic materials. This contributes to enhance comprehension of catalytic reactions and provides insight into degradation behavior. 4.2 Energy materials screening To achieve the optimal performance of energy materials, the systematic screening of electrocatalytic activity is essential for accumulating diverse data. However, this process is time-consuming and requires a substantial number of samples. In contrast, the utilization of SECM enables rapid screening of the characteristics of various materials, facilitating efficient decision-making for rational material selection [132–134]. Moreover, it is essential to verify the correlation between the activity of energy materials and the performance of actual devices. In this chapter, SECM provides reliable data to ensure improved functionality under real device operating conditions. Notably, SECM can target materials for energy storage devices, not limited to energy conversion systems. Xin et al. conducted a comparative analysis of ORR characteristics among various catalysts, including pure MoSe2, reduced graphene oxide (rGO), a physical mixture of MoSe2 and rGO (MoSe2 + rGO), and bilayer catalysts of MoSe2 and rGO (MoSe2@rGO) using RC mode [135]. The catalysts were deposited on a glassy carbon (GC) substrate (Fig. 6 a). In the RC mode screening, both the tip and substrate competitively participated in the ORR, consuming oxygen on both sides [94,136]. The screening results revealed that MoSe2@rGO exhibited the most significant difference in tip current (Δi), indicating that more oxygen was reduced on the substrate compared to the tip, establishing the substrate as the most active candidate (Fig. 6b). This enhanced catalytic activity was attributed to the layered structure of MoSe2@rGO, where the conductive rGO facilitated the electron transfer to the substrate and prevented aggregation of MoSe2 sheets [137,138]. Furthermore, the layered configuration provided increased interlayer spacing within MoSe2, enhancing electrolyte access to active edge sites [139,140]. The electrochemical screening results were corroborated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) data obtained using the rotating disk electrode (RDE) setup (Fig. 6c), closely approaching that of Pt/C. This underscores the efficacy of MoSe2@rGO as an ORR catalyst. This investigation effectively employed visualization techniques to enable a direct and simultaneous comparison of ORR activity across diverse catalyst structures. Li et al. evaluated the ORR activity of various iron-phthalocyanine-based polymers (PFePc) as a function of their dimensional structure [141]. It is widely acknowledged that the properties of electrocatalysts are closely associated with both their surface characteristics and structural configuration [142]. In their study, the authors synthesized 2D-G-PFePc, featuring PFePc layers surrounding a central graphene layer, and 3D-G-PFePc, featuring PFePc monolayers grown longitudinally on graphene. Analysis of TG/SC mapping images revealed that the tip current of 3D-G-PFePc was higher than that of 2D-G-PFePc, indicating significantly enhanced ORR activity (Fig. 6d). To provide a comprehensive overview of the ORR kinetics of 3D-G-PFePC, the half-wave potential (E 1/2), kinetic current density (j k), mass activity (MA) at 0.9 V, Tafel slope, and average intrinsic turnover frequency (TOF) were presented in a single plot (Fig. 6e). Remarkably, 3D-G-PFePc exhibited superior performance across all these kinetic parameters compared with 2D-G-PFePc. These outcomes were anticipated from the hierarchical structure of the hetero-nanosheets, facilitating the efficient exposure of the active sites, Fe-N4, coupled with the enhanced charge-transfer rates resulting from the synergistic interaction with graphene [143,144]. Moreover, considering the exceptional catalytic performance of 3D-G-PFePc, it is plausible to extrapolate its suitability for integration into ZOB systems designed for energy storage via the ORR [145]. In the discharge voltage profiled at the current density of 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6f), 3D-G-PFePc exhibited the highest specific capacity of 815 mA h g−1. In addition, when incorporated into a quasi-solid-state battery, 3D-G-PFePc exhibited exceptional cyclic stability. The use of SECM enabled rapid screening and comparison of ORR currents, which is consistent with the intrinsic catalyst properties. This study also underscores the potential of 3D-G-PFePc as a high-performing catalyst in ZOBs, with implications for advancing energy storage systems [146]. Pan et al. explored the local activity and selectivity of N-doped Co/Zn-carbon nanofiber membrane (Co/Zn@NCF) catalyst at various potential and temperature [147]. The ORR local activity and selectivity of Co/Zn@NCF were assessed using RC and SG/TC mode, respectively. In comparison to NCF (N-doped carbon nanotube), Co/Zn@NCF exhibited higher current across a range of substrate potentials from 0.87 to 0.67 V (vs. RHE), indicating superior ORR activity. In the SG/TC mode, the intermediate product of H2O2 of the ORR was probed with a tip potential of 1.36 V. Although Co/Zn@NCF exhibits greater ORR activity compared to NCF, the tip current attributed to H2O2 production in the voltage range of 0.87 to 0.67 V is nearly identical for both Co/Zn@NCF and NCF. This suggests that the ORR reaction of Co/Zn@NCF predominantly leads to H2O production, involving the 4e− reduction. The catalytic property of Co/Zn@NCF was further evaluated at temperatures of 15, 25, and 40 °C at the substrate potential of 0.67 V. The ORR activity of both NCF and Co/Zn@NCF increased with operating temperature increasing from 15 to 25 °C due to the faster kinetics. In contrast, H2O2 production remained consistent at both temperatures. As the temperature increased to 40 °C, the activity of Co/Zn@NCF remained nearly the same, suggesting that the optimized operating temperature for ORR is around 25 °C. Moreover, the Co/Zn@NCF also exhibits elevated OER activity in the range of 1.57 to 1.67 V, substantiating the potential of Co/Zn@NCF as a bifunctional catalyst. Additionally, Co/Zn@NCF was further applied to both liquid and solid-state ZOB. Due to its heightened activity in both ORR and OER, the ZOB demonstrates remarkable reversibility and stability over 4000 cycles. Zhang et al. conducted screening of the electrochemical activity of carbon-aerogel-supported Pt-based nanoparticles as a novel ORR mediator for MgOBs [148]. The activities of various ORR mediators were comparatively evaluated through line scanning using SECM in TG/SC mode. During the ORR, oxygen is generated at the tip and subsequently diffuses toward the substrate, producing an electrochemical reduction current. Interestingly, the Pt-Zn/carbon aerogel (CA) exhibited the highest average current value (8180 nA) in Fig. 6(g–j), implying that it possesses the highest activity for ORR. The enhanced performance of Pt-Zn/CA can be ascribed to the improved electron transport capability of CA. The doping of Zn results in the formation of Pt-rich surface, mitigating the melting problem by widening the d-band gap. Additionally, this process utilizes carbon aerogels with high specific surface areas to improve the activity of the catalyst [149]. Furthermore, the Pt-Zn/CA delivered a remarkable discharge capacity of 1349.46 mA h g−1 in the discharge voltage profile of the MgOBs at a current density of 5 mA cm−2, as shown in Fig. 6(k). Notably, the MgOB performance of each mediator consistently aligns with the TG/SC scan results, underscoring the robust applicability of SECM within the field of battery research. In conclusion, the systematic scanning method of SECM proves instrumental in determining the optimal composition and structures of energy materials, thereby enhancing the overall performance of energy systems. This approach not only provides a comprehensive understanding of electrocatalysis but also plays a pivotal role in facilitating informed decision-making regarding material selection for energy conversion and storage systems. 4.3 In-situ investigation of gas behavior The investigation of gas bubble behavior in catalytic reactions, particularly in processes like water electrolysis, is essential for understanding and optimizing electrocatalytic processes. This investigation focuses on three pivotal stages: nucleation, growth, and separation of gas bubbles [150]. Effective bubble separation is critical because inadequate management can passivate active catalytic sites, hindering subsequent reactions impeding the nucleation and growth of subsequent bubbles [151]. This emphasizes the importance of understanding and efficiently controlling bubble behavior while evaluating the performance of catalysts [152]. Traditional methods for studying gas bubble behavior have faced challenges including limitations in observing fine-scale details, inadequate high-resolution measurements for real-time observations, and difficulties in accurately controlling and measuring the impact of catalysts and electrode surface characteristics. To overcome these limitations, SECM has emerged as a valuable tool. SECM enables researchers to conduct catalytic redox reaction with microelectrodes, providing a more comprehensive understanding of gas bubble formation and dynamic behavior. In this way, SECM addresses the drawbacks of traditional approaches and significantly enhances the capability to study gas bubble behavior. Wang et al. firstly introduced the application of SECCM to visualize the bubble nucleation behavior during the HER on polycrystalline Pt substrates [153]. Bubble nucleation was identified through distinct peaks of high intensity (i b p) identified by CV curve measurements performed within the meniscus of SECCM. Based on SECCM mapping results using i b p at various locations on polycrystalline Pt, it was confirmed that the non-uniform activation energy for H2 bubble nucleation on the Pt surface. Interestingly, this investigation challenges the conventional belief that electrochemical gas bubbling reactions should predominantly occur in areas with highest catalytic activity [154]. These insights offer novel perspectives for designing substrates that facilitate efficient bubble removal in electrochemical processes. Nicholas et al. further expanded on this research, particularly delving into the dynamics of the reaction and contributing to various studies on bubble nucleation in diverse environments [155]. Liu et al. employed SECCM to visualize the electrochemical processes of bubbles on MoS2 electrodes with different microstructures [156]. During the measurement of the CV curve using a 2.7-μm-radius micropipette, bubble nucleation generated a distinct peak of i b p. The i b p of the nanostructured MoS2 surface (Fig. 7 a) was noted to be lower at low potential compared to at the flat MoS2 surface (Fig. 7b). This result indicates that nanostructured MoS2 can significantly reduce the surface supersaturation for gas-bubble nucleation, resulting in a notable increase in bubble detachment. In addition, the electrochemical HER activity generated at −0.7 V vs. Ag/AgCl was mapped. No clear correlation between H2 bubble nucleation current and HER activity was observed. While SECCM has effectively demonstrated bubble nucleation behavior across various interfaces, the challenge of obtaining high-resolution and continuous mapping images persists due to the hopping mode used for SECCM imaging. The emergence of bubbles on the substrate introduces resistance through the ohmic drop between the tip and substrate [157]. Consequently, the utilization of FB mode has proven successful in visualizing bubble formation. Bülteret al. demonstrated real-time feedback images depicting the formation of bubbles at the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer within graphite anodes for lithium secondary batteries, utilizing 2,5-ditertbutyl-1,4-dimethoxy benzene as a redox mediator [158]. This demonstration highlights that diverse mapping images can be acquired by employing various modes of SECM. As indicated by previous research, rapid separation of bubbles and high catalytic activity are critical aspects in gas-evolution reactions. Lim et al. designed bifunctional porous transport layers (PTLs) incorporating Ti channels, which are favorable for the separation and diffusion of bubbles [159]. They employed SG/TC mode to electrochemically observe bubble behavior. During the OER, oxygen bubbles generated at the surface of the active layer (IrO2) escaped through the porous PTL and were subsequently detected at the UME tip. Fig. 7(c) presents line scan images measured along the hydrophilic, hydrophobic, and amphiphilic directions while applying potential of 1.15 and 0.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl for the OER and ORR, respectively. Along the hydrophilic line, the results reveal a low O2 flux of 60 pmol cm−2 s−1. In contrast, the hydrophobic channel exhibits a high O2 flux over 120 pmol cm−2 s−1 due to the facilitated bubble detachment and ejection [160]. The photos of the PTLs during the electrolysis reaction clearly depict the efficient transport of bubble through a patterned membrane with a hydrophilic channel compared with that through a hydrophobic membrane. The hydrophilic membrane demonstrates the formation of the large oxygen bubble at the surface. Lim et al. successfully identified the preferred path of gas emissions through the hydrophobic pathways using SG/TC mode, conclusively demonstrating the importance of bubble transport engineering [161–164]. A comprehensive understanding of the oxygen-transport dynamics during charging and discharging processes is also critical for optimizing performance in LOBs [165]. When a LOB is discharged, oxygen flows into the cell through the GDE. During recharging, oxygen molecules are formed and escape out of the cell through the GDE. One of the challenges for LOBs is facilitating oxygen transport for the ORR by promoting the recharge process to decompose Li2O2 [166]. Therefore, numerous efforts have been undertaken to address the issue of incomplete decomposition of Li2O2, leading to challenges such as pore clogging or passivation of the GDE [167]. Nevertheless, accurate analyses of oxygen behavior on the positive electrode surface remain considerably constrained. The main obstacle lies in the intricate analysis of gaseous states within an in-situ system. This limitation arises from the inherent complexities associated with scrutinizing reactions occurring at three-phase boundaries [168]. Schwager et al. firstly proposed a novel pulsed amperometric detection (PAD) method for SECM, allowing the analysis of oxygen behavior without interference from passivation layers at the tip [169]. In addition, the permeation of oxygen was analyzed with respect to the thickness of the GDE using the SG/TC mode of SECM. Fig. 7(d) illustrates the setup for analyzing reactions at the three-phase interface with gas supply. However, the SECM analysis for LOBs faces challenges due to passivation layer formed on the tip during the ORR. This passivation layer was identified as Li2O2 through a comparative experiment under TBAClO4 and LiClO4 salt conditions, the deposited Li2O2 hinders electron transfer, disrupting accurate analysis. They successfully eliminated the influence of the passivation layer, enabling analysis of oxygen behavior by introducing the oxidation current for Li2O2 decomposition through a pulse system. Fig. 7(e) presents the SECM measurement results in 1 M LiClO4 in DMSO solution. Using this setup, an attempt was made to analyze the influx of oxygen by detecting the ORR current at the tip. When a constant potential (−1 V) was applied at a tip as for line 1, the measured current gradually decreased (line 3), indicating passivation by Li2O2. To eliminate Li2O2, the PAD method, involving the stimulating oxidation potential between reduction potential for measurements, was implemented (line 2). Line 5 represents the current from the decomposition of Li2O2 when the oxidation potential is applied. As a result, Line 4, representing oxygen behavior, demonstrates a consistent reduction current, in contrast to line 3. Furthermore, it was demonstrated that the mass transport of oxygen decreases with increasing GDE thickness by comparing 60–250 μm GDE using the PAD method. Schwager et al. established the groundwork for analyzing the behavior of oxygen in a LOB system using the SECM-based PAD method. Subsequently, Schwager et al. identified the formation of a soluble intermediate superoxide (O2 −) using RC, SG/TC mode and the PAD method of SECM. They proposed the utilization of a false-color map to analyze oxygen behavior concerning the distances between the UME tip and GDE substrate, enabling visualization of specific regions where each species has a predominant influence [170]. As oxygen flows into the cell, it undergoes reduction, leading to the formation of O2 − on the GDE surface. During this process, two electrochemical reactions are analyzed based on the pulse applied to the tip. The results of reduction pulses indicate that soluble products (O2 −) tend to be preferentially produced near the GDE and subsequently diffuse into the electrolyte. Fig. 7(f) present false-color maps of the reduction current during pulse applied to the tip, illustrating the dependence on the distance between the GDE and tip. These false-color maps effectively identify the oxygen flux. The appearance of the oxidation current value, where O2 − is oxidized to oxygen at a distance of less than 75 μm, suggesting a diminishing influence of O2 − over d = 75 μm. Furthermore, the decrease in the ORR area (60–80 s, 180–200 s) indicates oxygen consumption at the GDE. The reduction current, where O2 − is formed at the tip, is observed only at distances of less than d = 25 μm, demonstrating that the tip body interrupts the flux of oxygen. These results underscore that the interpretation of SECM data requires careful consideration of the SECM design. Finally, Bülter et al. electrochemically visualized the oxygen flux in 2D images using SECM and the PAD method to determine the oxygen permeation rate and to validate that pore clogging does not a crucial factor in cell failure [171]. In the LOB, oxygen penetrates the GDE both before and after discharge. Compared with the bare GDE, the discharged electrode exhibits a decreased current of 0.2 nA, which is 40% of the highest current of the bare GDE. This reduction is attributed to hindered oxygen transport caused by Li2O2 with pore clogging. The solid Li2O2 generated on the pores obstructs the diffusion pathways of oxygen, resulting in a diminished oxygen signal at the UME in the discharged state compared with the bare GDE. Interestingly, an oxygen signal remains detectable at the microelectrode, even in cases where the GDE was presumed to be discharged (i.e., not entirely obstructed by Li2O2). These findings suggest that pore clogging, induced by ORR product deposition, is not the sole reason for cell degradation in LOBs. Moreover, this research holds significance in visually capturing the influx of oxygen for in-situ observations. In summary, SECCM provides a more profound understanding of the gas evolution reaction during water electrolysis with a catalyst. It also enables quantification of crucial characteristics such as gas desorption and movement within the PTL using SG/TC mode of SECM. Moreover, gaining insight into behavior of gaseous species in LOBs is facilitated by in-situ analysis and visualization in a liquid medium. The application of the PAD mode of SECM is expected to further expand the scope of research in gas-based chemistry. 4.4 Verification of electrochemical mechanism Advancing high-performance materials for energy conversion and storage systems relies on validating electrochemical mechanisms [172,173]. Electrocatalysis encounters challenges arising from complex reaction pathways involving various intermediates and by-products, making it difficult to identify the precise reaction routes. These reactions occur at the molecular level, demanding fine-grained real-time observations. To overcome these challenges, advanced techniques such as SECM are used to gain a deeper understanding of electrochemical processes. SECM employs UME in close proximity to the substrate, enabling measurements with high spatial resolution. It facilitates molecular exchange experiments with microelectrodes, enabling research on formation of intermediate and by-product and decomposition processes [40]. In summary, SECM significantly contributes to an enhanced comprehension of electrochemical mechanism and plays a pivotal role in advancing research within the field of electrocatalysis. Tavakkoli et al. proposed a method for identifying the primary active sites for the OER on various substrates using SG/TC mode [174]. During this process, the potential for OER on the substrate was applied through CV (depicted by the black line), the response current (red line) was monitored while keeping the tip potential at 0.3 V for ORR to detect oxygen produced from substrate (Fig. 8 a and b). The porous catalyst layer on the GC substrate exhibited a rapid increase in current along with oxygen generation. However, this increased current gradually diminished (Fig. 8a), suggesting that oxygen formed on the catalyst quickly transfers to the tip and then diffuses into the bulk electrolyte. Conversely, on the Ni substrate, a stepwise increase in ORR current was observed during cycling, indicating delayed oxygen transport from catalyst layer. (Fig. 8b) The slower oxygen transport observed on the Ni substrate implies that OER occurs at deeper sites compared to GC substrate, suggesting that active sites for OER may exist not only on the catalyst surface but also at the catalyst/substrate interface, dependent on the substrate material. SECM proves valuable in analyzing active sites in porous catalyst layers by monitoring changes in current due to molecular diffusion. Chakrabarty et al. determined the ORR mechanism pathway for a microsphere rGO-ZnCo2O4 catalyst via SG/TC mode [175]. During ORR, oxygen undergoes a four-electron reduction to produce H2O, while an alternative route forms the hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as intermediate with two electrons. To identify the mechanism, an ORR onset potential of 0.87 V and H2O2 oxidation potential of 1.7 V were applied to the substrate and tip, respectively. Despite of significant increased substrate current within the scanning region, there was no detectable change in tip current. This indicates that H2O is formed more widely than H2O2 due to the dominance of the four-electron reduction pathway on the rGO-ZnCo2O4 catalyst surface during the ORR process. Furthermore, the study noted a substantial reduction in the formation of H2O2 in rGO-ZnCo2O4 compared to bare ZnCo2O4. This reduction can be attributed to the enhanced ORR activity at the interface between rGO and ZnCo2O4, as well as the increased surface area. Therefore, this research underscores the potential applications of SECM in accurately verifying the fundamental ORR mechanism of catalysts [176]. Li et al. introduced a modified TG/SC mode, referred to as reactive TG/SC (RTG/SC) mode [177], to provide insights into key factors influencing the ORR behavior of Ti, particularly altered by the spontaneously formed oxide film [178]. The advanced RTG/SC mode utilizes a 25 µm Ti UME and a 62.5 µm Pt electrode for the reactive tip and substrate electrodes, respectively, achieving a high collection efficiency of 97.2% (Fig. 8c). During LSV, Ti UME generated ORR products. The Pt UME exhibited selective detection of H2O2 under at a potential of 1.41/1.18 V vs. RHE in both acidic and alkaline solutions, with pH values of 6.9/11.6, respectively. The RTG/SC current of the Ti electrode with passivated native oxide (P-Ti) reveals a rising tip current (i tip) with polarization. Meanwhile, the substrate current (|i sub|) displays a peak at −0.35 V vs. RHE, followed by a decrease, indicating the production of H2O2 under weak polarization and the production of H2O under stronger polarization (Fig. 8d). Compared with P-Ti, the RTG/SC current of the electrochemically reduced electrode (EA-Ti) shows a positively shifted ORR onset potential and an earlier appearance of the diffusion-controlled region, indicating enhanced ORR activity (Fig. 8e). Overall, the ORR of Ti involves H2O2 production reaction, displaying sensitivity to anionic species in neutral media and a preference for H2O2 production reactions in alkaline media. The improved selectivity of H2O2 production is attributed to stabilization effects resulting from a reduced activation energy due to the strong hydrogen bonding between O and H atoms, as well as electrostatic interactions between O and Ti atoms. The reduced ORR activity in neutral NaCl is due to interference with O2 adsorption by Cl−, which acts as an observer without altering the reaction pathway. This study provides a theoretical approach and potential guidance for ORR studies on oxide-covered metals. Liang et al. studied the HER mechanism on Ni electrodes in alkaline media with SG/TC mode [179]. They utilized two UMEs with identical diameter, positioning the Ni UME at the bottom to induce the HER and the Pt UME at the top to monitor the hydrogen produced from the Ni UME. Ni hydroxide, Ni(OH)2, and NiOOH (low-valence-state of Ni oxide components) were generated at the Ni UME by CV scans, varying the upper limit potential (E ul) from −0.2 to 0.45 V (Fig. 8f). The HER activity of Ni oxide components was measured at the Pt UME when the Ni UME was at −1.2 V. The Pt UME current increases as E ul increases up to 0.062 V, attributed to the adsorption of hydroxyl ions and the subsequent formation of low-valence state oxides (Ni(OH)2) on the Ni surface, promoting the water dissociation, Volmer step. When E ul exceeds 0.062 V, the Pt UME current decreases due to the formation of the high-valence state oxide (NiOOH), hindering electron transfer at the interface and hydrogen adsorption at Ni sites. Thus, these results indicate that Ni(OH)2 is more favorable for the HER than NiOOH, promoting the Volmer step at the surface of metallic Ni [130]. Furthermore, the adsorbed hydrogen on the Ni was quantified using the SI mode during the HER by titrating the redox mediator, ferrocenemethanol+ (FcMeOH+) at the Pt UME to analyze the formation of hydrogen adsorbates (Hads) in CV. The charge density exhibited two sections; Rx1 with a charge density below 400 μC cm−2 and Rx2 with a charge density above 400C cm−2. In the Rx1 section, Hads was not formed, and the Ni metal participated in the titration reaction with FcMeOH+, resulting in an increasing charge density due to the reduction of Ni oxide, exposing more Ni metal on the surface up to −0.92 V. In the Rx2 section from −1.1 to −1.15 V, hydrogen adsorbed on the electrode, and the charge density originated from the reaction between Hads and FcMeOH+. Since the adsorption of hydrogen was the slowest step before −1.1 V, it was suggested that the Volmer step served as the rate-determining step (RDS) of the HER. This finding was further confirmed by the application of the Frumkin isotherm equation describing the coverage ratio of Hads [180]. Overall, this study utilized the SECM to elucidate the mechanism of the HER on Ni electrode by thoroughly exploiting its operational modes. Ahn et al. conducted directly titration the intermediates of CoPi catalysts during the OER in a water-filled environment using the SI mode, employing two redox mediators, 1,1′-ferrocenedimethanol (FcDM) and K2IrCl6 as titrants [181]. CoPi catalysts exhibit CoIII and CoIV intermediates during the OER, but determining the oxidation state of Co has been challenging due to the rapid reaction of CoIV with water. In the SI mode, the CoIII and CoIV were obtained from CoPi through the oxidative pulse potential at the substrate and titrated by CV at the tip. The charge density obtained with FcDM gradually increased with a short plateau with range of 30–40 mV, corresponding to the substrate potential (Fig. 8g). The first plateau at 810 mV corresponds to the first one-electron oxidation of CoPi (CoII) to CoIII. The active cobalt density was calculated as 11 Co atoms nm−2 from the charge plateau of CoIII/II, surpassing previously reported values (3–7 atoms nm−2) derived from crystal packing. The estimation gains significant importance due to the challenging nature of directly measuring the actual catalytic properties of surface atoms. Selective titration of CoIV, independent from CoIII, was achieved using the IrCl6 3− redox mediators, with the charge density plot indicating the CoIV/III transition at 750 mV (Fig. 8h). Pseudo-first-order rate constants were calculated by considering the inherent time delay in the bipotentiostat switching. The rate constants of CoIII and CoIV were determined as 0.19 and over 2 s−1, respectively, using FcDM and K2IrCl6. CoIII also exhibited unexpectedly rapid kinetics, comparable to conventional catalysts, suggesting its potential as an important active species in next-generation catalysts. In summary, this study represents the first electrochemically determination of the active site density and the relatively high rate constant of CoIII in CoPi, and it also verified the reliability of the SI mode. Tang et al. conducted a comprehensive quantitative analysis of active site density and visualized the local distribution of reaction activity in electrocatalysts, particularly considering their morphology for ZOB [182]. The local reactivity of the catalyst was visually compared by utilizing the TG/SC mode. SI-SECM was employed to quantitatively characterize the active site density, actively participating in the electrocatalytic reaction (Fig. 8i). The plots of integrated charge (Q tip) from SI-SECM (Fig. 8j) indicate that the catalyst with a coexistence of micropores and mesoporous pores exhibits an active site density 3.57 × 1014 sites cm−2 with a utilization rate of 97.92%. In contrast, the catalyst with a relatively dense structure and micropores has an active site density of 1.07 × 1014 sites cm−2, and the utilization rate of active sites is only 18.40%. This study highlights the critical role of active site density and the utilization rate in determining electrocatalytic performance, addressing the limitations of prevalent oxygen electrocatalysts due to inappropriate nanostructural design. Furthermore, the catalyst featuring coexistence of micro/mesoporous pore exhibits outstanding ZOB performance, including high power density (264.34 mW cm−2), large specific capacity (814.09 mA h g−1), and long cycle life (over 200 h). As discussed above, SECM proves to be a suitable methodology for identifying electrochemical mechanism. This tool not only clarifies reaction mechanisms but also reveals intermediates through various scanning modes. In essence, SECM serves as an indispensable tool for uncovering the complexity of materials, which holds promise for further advancements in energy conversion and storage systems. 4.5 Evaluating kinetics of electrocatalytic reaction Evaluating reaction kinetics is vital for understanding reaction rates, optimizing conditions, and designing efficient systems in electrochemistry. Kinetic studies unveil complex reaction mechanisms and aid in selecting superior electrode materials. In addition, it plays an integral role in advancing applications and technologies by optimizing performance, enhancing stability, and refining processes. While conventional methods like Tafel analysis and Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy have limitations, such as complexity of analyzing intricate reaction mechanisms or the requirement for sophisticated modeling, SECM emerges as a promising tool for a deeper and simple understanding of reaction kinetics. Especially, SECM proves to be a powerful tool for exploring the charge-transfer dynamics at different interfaces, such as solid/liquid or liquid/liquid interfaces. The pioneering use of SECM to explore reaction kinetics was introduced for dye-sensitized solar cell systems by Bard et al. [86]. Quantitative analysis of rate constants is performed by fitting normalized experimental approach curves, specifically the tip current ( i T , Z ) according to the distance (z) from the substrate relative to bulk current ( i T , Z / i T , ∞ ) to the Butler-Volmer equation [183] or an analytical function suggested by Cournut and Lefrou for a first-order reaction [184]. The apparent rate constant ( k a p p ), representing the rate of the electrochemical reaction under specific experimental conditions, can be determined using the Butler-Volmer equation. This equation incorporates the exchange current ( i 0 ), encompassing the rate constant, which can be estimated through experimental data and modeling. The effective rate constant ( k e f f i ), representing the overall efficiency of mass transport and reaction kinetics at the electrode surface, can be evaluated using the equation ( k e f f i = κ D 0 / r T ), where κ is obtained from the aforementioned analytical function, and r T is the diameter of the UME tip. This comprehensive analysis allows for a profound understanding of the reaction mechanisms and kinetics in electrochemical systems. Selva et al. conducted a comparative analysis of the HOR kinetics on nanoporous gold (NPG), Pt, and platinum-decorated nanoporous gold (Pt-NPG) as substrate materials using FB mode [185]. In this system, proton (H+) reduction takes place at the tip, while H2 oxidation occurs at the substrate. As the H2 oxidation process is surface-sensitive, a positive feedback current is only observed when a substrate exhibits exceptional electrocatalytic activity, facilitating the reoxidation of H2 to H+. The approach curve for the NPG substrate gradually decreased as the tip reached the substrate, indicating the poor catalytic activity of the NPG surface for further hydrogen oxidation to H+. In contrast, Pt-NPG exhibited a significant increase in the tip current due to efficient H+ regeneration (Fig. 9 a). A linear correlation between k a p p obtained from the approach curve and the substrate potential was observed, with Pt-NPG showing a notably higher k a p p value [186,187] (Fig. 9b). Thus, it is affirmed that the NPG surface is inert for H2 oxidation but becomes activated when decorated with a small amount of Pt. Kumar et al. also evaluated the reaction kinetics of the photoelectrochemical (PEC) water oxidation process, with a focus on incorporating cobalt borate (Co-Bi) into bismuth vanadate (BiVO4) photoanodes [188]. After photocharging, k e f f i for pristine BiVO4 (BV) and BV/Co-Bi-3 were determined to be 9.05 and 11.76 × e−3 cm s−1, respectively. This result indicates that the presence of Co-Bi, serving as a hole collector, enhances the photocurrent of the BV photoanode, further activating OER. The effective heterogeneous hole transfer rate constant is calculated based on the normalized apparent heterogeneous charge transfer rate constant by fitting approach curves in the feedback mode. Yu et al. investigated the impact of surface modification of BiVO4 with a cocatalyst, NiFe-LDH (layered double hydroxide), using the FB mode [189]. Through the measurement of approach curves, the charge-transfer dynamics and charge-carrier recombination process associated with PEC water splitting were evaluated. The normal hole-transfer rate constant (k h+ 0) and normal electron-transfer rate constant (k e− 0) were calculated using redox mediators of [Fe(CN)6]3− and [Fe(CN)6]4−, respectively. The obtained k e f f i of BiVO4 was larger than that of BiVO4/NiFe-LDH under illumination (Fig. 9c). By modifying the surface concentration to alter k e f f i , the regeneration rate constant of the catalyst ( k ′ o x ) was determined. Interestingly, the k ′ o x values for both BiVO4 and BiVO4/NiFe-LDH were very similar (3.43 × 105 and 3.32 × 105 mol−1 cm3 s−1, respectively). Furthermore, the ratio of k h+ 0 / k e− 0 of BiVO4/NiFe-LDH was five times larger than that of BiVO4 (Fig. 9c and d). This result indicates that the NiFe-LDH cocatalyst may not act as an electrocatalyst to increase the surface charge-carrier transfer rate but rather suppressed electron back transfer, reducing surface recombination. SECM evaluation allows exploration of the heterogeneous charge-transfer kinetics at various interfaces. Niu et al. explored the HER kinetics of NiCoP-grain-anchored Ti3C2T x MXene (NiCoP@MXene) in an alkaline medium using SG/TC mode [190]. Employing an electrocatalyst with a heterogeneous interface is a strategy to lower the energy barrier for water dissociation by adjusting the adsorption energy of intermediates during the transition stage. The SECM map revealed that NiCoP@MXene exhibited a higher tip current compared to NiCoP or MXene, implying superior catalytic HER activity. H2 is generated at the NiCoP@MXene and then captured and oxidized at the Pt tip through the HOR. The tip current increases as the temperature rises from 25 to 65 °C (Fig. 9e), signifying a reduction in the activation energy barrier (E a) and an accelerated reaction rate. Based on the Arrhenius equation, E a was calculated to be 31.9 kJ mol−1 (Fig. 9f). This result aligns with the value of 31.4 kJ mol−1 obtained from the exchange current density in macro-scale electrochemical analysis, thereby validating the application of SECM for kinetic analysis [191]. For the LOBs, exploring the rate constant offers crucial insights into optimizing redox mediators and enhancing the cell performance. Theoretically, a RM with a redox potential closely matching the standard potential of Li2O2 (E 0 = 2.96 V vs. Li/Li+) is expected to be more effective, resulting in a significantly reduced overpotential [192]. However, various studies have suggested that a RM operating at low redox potentials might not effectively decompose Li2O2 because the decomposition kinetics of Li2O2 are contingent on the kinetics of the RM [193]. Nevertheless, there is a current deficiency in research on the kinetics of RMs for LOBs, and further analysis can be conducted using SECM. Chen et al. proposed a novel approach to evaluate the reaction rate between the RM and Li2O2 by examining the apparent rate constant k a p p measured using the feedback approach curve of SECM [194]. Their study focused on understanding the influence of the oxidizing center of the RM and its steric hindrance degree. By analyzing the correlations among the redox potentials of the RM, the standard heterogeneous electron-transfer rate constant (k°), and k a p p , they identified crucial factors governing Li2O2 oxidation. Intriguingly, no observable correlation between k a p p and k° was found (Fig. 9g), indicating that the Li2O2 oxidation is not governed by electron-transfer kinetics but rather by adsorption of the RM on the Li2O2 surface. Considering the Li2O2 oxidation rate by RM using the k a p p calculation, nitroxy radicals are recommended due to the low steric hindrances when approaching the Li2O2 surface. Krueger et al. introduced a methodology for calculating the rate constant of the RM in Li2O2 decomposition by evaluating approach curves using the FB mode [195]. They further explored the challenges associated with incorporating an ionic liquid into the LOB system by examining the rate constant of the RM in various ionic liquids. The evaluation of rate constants for representative RMs in LOBs with different solvents revealed that the rate constant for the ionic liquid was relatively low compared to glyme-based solvents. Fig. 9(h) presents the approach curves for various RMs in a diglyme solution, along with the calculated rate constant. Furthermore, a heterogeneous rate constant, k e f f i , which considered D 0 , the tip’s geometry, and the sample arrangement, was proposed. The k e f f i for the ionic liquid was relatively low compared to the values for the glyme-based solvents. Through comparison of rate constants for previously reported RMs, the study provides insight into RM and solvent selection in the LOB system based on rate constants. To design an efficient RM with optimal kinetics and a low charging potential in LOBs, Ahn et al. suggested analysis of the heterogeneous electron transfer rate constant, k e f f i [196]. As the distance between the UME tip and Li2O2 decrease, higher current values indicate a higher k e f f i . The calculations were conducted using a 12.5-μm-diameter gold microdisc approaching at 1.5 μm s−1 in a LiTFSI solution. In Fig. 9(i), the correlation between k e f f i of four RMs (FC, MAZO, MPT, and TEMPO) and their redox potential, ranging from 3.5 to 3.9 V vs. Li/Li+, is presented. Achieving a balance between a low redox potential and fast kinetics (high k e f f i ) requires careful RM design, focusing on minimizing reorganization energy through modifications in the electrolyte environment. Ahn et al. substantiated the LOB mechanism and identified the rate-determining step through SECM. Overall, SECM stands out as a highly promising analytical tool for investigating charge transfer rates in reactions. The rate constants measured by SECM closely match the values obtained through previously reported analysis methods, ensuring the reliability of SECM analysis. The exploration of reaction kinetics holds significant importance across diverse fields, underscoring the importance of a deeper understanding and broader applications of SECM in the analysis of reaction kinetics. 4.6 Integrated analysis with other evaluation methods As previously elucidated, although SECM is a powerful tool for real-time electrochemical characterization, but its primary output is semi-qualitative information derived from currents in response to electrical potential. To address these limitations, current research endeavors are concentrated on the integration of spectroscopic instruments with SECM. This collaboration allows simultaneous collection of qualitative chemical information and quantitative currents in real-time [197]. This integration represents a significant advancement that promotes high-precision and comprehensive analysis of electrochemical reactions, particularly within energy conversion and storage systems. Wang et al. demonstrated influence of crystallographic orientation on the catalytic reaction of HOR in the anode reaction of a hydrogen fuel cell [186]. Their approach integrated SEM electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) with SECM imaging analysis. SEM EBSD revealed seven facets on the Pt surface along crystallographic planes (Fig. 10 a), with colors corresponding to (100), (110), and (111) crystallographic planes (red, green, and blue, respectively). Subsequently, TG/SC mode of SECM spatially imaged the tip current for HOR on the Pt surface (Fig. 10b), closely aligning with the grain orientation observed in the SEM EBSD inverse pole figure (IPF) maps. Integrating SECM imaging and EBSD IPF map revealed that surface catalytic activity was most enhanced on the (111) plane, followed by (110) and (100). This study visually established the correlation between the HOR catalytic activity and crystallographic orientation, establishing a structure–reactivity relationship. The SECM system, when combined with structural analysis techniques of EBSD, enables the visual verification of the electrochemical aspect based on the catalyst's structure. Mayer et al. utilized CV-SECM in collaboration with SEM and XPS to assess the composition-dependent catalytic activity of Sn/SnO x catalysts for CO2 reduction [198]. The catalyst layer of Sn/SnO x comprises a mixture of three species: Sn, SnO, and SnO2, which participate in a chemical reaction (CO2RF) to convert CO2 into formic acid (HCOOH or HCOO−). The catalytic activity, dependent on the composition of the Sn/SnO x catalyst layer before and after electroreduction, was investigated using XPS spectral analysis along with SG/TC mode. CV-SECM mapping results validated that the formation of formic acid from CO2RF was initiated by the substrate at −1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Specifically, peak intensities of the as-prepared and the electro-reduced Sn/SnO x catalyst layer were compared at −1.25 and 3 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The electro-reduced catalyst layer at −1.25 V exhibited the highest catalytic activity, producing significantly greater amounts of HCOO− and COad. As confirmed by XPS analysis, SnO2 emerged as the predominant species in the electro-reduced Sn/SnO x catalyst layer, underscoring its role as the optimal catalyst for CO2 reduction. The superior catalytic performance of SnO2 can be attributed to the increased surface area and the abundance of surface defects in catalyst particles, as evident from diverse shapes and sizes observed in SEM images. The integration of CV-SECM mapping and regional surface analysis techniques, such as XPS, effectively assessed catalyst activity while considering the compositional heterogeneity of the catalyst.
