For LOBs, Schwager et al. identified the formation of O2 − during discharging using fluorescence microscopy in conjunction with SECM [170]. As oxygen flowed into the cell through the GDE, it underwent reduction to generate O2 −. Fluorescence microscopy, equipped with a lens irradiating a 470 nm laser to excite the fluorescent molecule (4-Chloro-7-nitrobenzo-2-oxa-1,3-diazole, NBD-Cl) reacting with O2 − and emitting light, confirmed the rapid generation of O2 − within a few seconds (Fig. 10c). While the SECM mapping image visually represents electrochemical reactions on the electrode surface, it does not identify the specific material responsible. Through fluorescence microscopy, it was established that O2 gas is being reduced to O2 −, providing insights into the spatiotemporal dynamics of gas-containing electrochemical systems. This integrated analysis demonstrated O2 − formation, enhancing the understanding of such systems beyond single SECM analysis. Edgecomb et al. introduced an innovative analytical approach by integrating SECCM with UV-vis fluorescence spectroscopy to in-situ detect the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) during the ORR process in a fuel cell (Fig. 10d) [199]. The catalyst layer was infused with the 6-carboxyfluorescein dye (6CFL) to facilitate ROS detection, exhibiting a fluorescence peak within the 515 to 650 nm range. As ROS formed, these fluorescence peaks were quenched, resulting in decreased intensity. Rapid in-situ analysis was crucial due to the short existence of ROS. In-situ LSV analysis through SECCM was conducted using an O2-purged H2SO4 electrolyte, revealing an ORR peak at around 0.3 V vs. RHE associated with H2O2 formation (Fig. 10e). In-situ UV-vis fluorescence spectroscopy of 6CFL at a fixed potential of 0.3 V vs. RHE, using Ar- or O2-purged H2SO4 electrolytes, confirmed a rapid decrease in the fluorescence peak in the O2-purged electrolyte, validating the association of ROS formation with H2O2 (Fig. 10f). This hybrid analysis effectively demonstrated the potential for ROS formation associated with cell degradation, providing spatial resolution of 10–20 μm for monitoring generation of ROS and H2O2 from catalyst active sites during ORR. The study underscores the contribution of comprehensive in-situ SECM hybrid analysis in detecting intermediates and analyzing reaction mechanisms. Steimecke et al. integrated the SG/TC mode with Raman spectroscopy for real-time characterization of the transition mechanism on Ni/Fe thin film electrodes during the OER at a specific location on the electrode (Fig. 10g) [200]. By employing SG/TC mode of SECM, the potential of both substrate and UME was incrementally increased to determine the potential-dependent electrochemical response of the Ni/Fe thin film. Notably, both the thin film and UME exhibited their highest values at 0.63 V vs. RHE when using a mixture with 15% Fe content (Fig. 10h). Raman spectra recorded at various potential revealed a diminishing trend at 475 and 557 cm−1 with increasing Fe content due to the Ni-O vibration of γ-NiOOH (Fig. 10i). Additionally, the ratio of absolute band intensities (I 475/I 557) decreased with increasing Fe content, suggesting the disordering of Ni oxide structure due to the presence of Fe atoms [201,202]. The in-situ Raman-SECM hybrid analysis establishes a direct correlation between structural changes and electrochemical characteristics at the same electrode position, offering novel insights into the relationships between material structure and electrochemical activity. In conclusion, the integration of advanced analytical techniques with SECM has emerged as a powerful strategy to gain profound insights into various electrochemical processes and material characteristics. Each investigation presented in this section underscores the capability of SECM hybrid techniques, when employed in conjunction with complementary methods, to offer a comprehensive understanding of complex electrochemical systems encompassing electrode morphology, composition, and electrochemical activity. The continuous development and application of these integrated approaches are essential for addressing fundamental challenges in electrochemistry and advancing the design of efficient electrochemical devices. 5 Conclusions and future perspective SECM methodology, with its spatiotemporal resolution, provides a powerful tool for visualizing local catalytic activity and surface topography. This provides a comprehensive understanding of electrocatalytic processes occurring in the field of energy conversion and storage systems. In this review, we summarized the key research findings and recent advancements in catalyst design, mechanism analysis, and degradation behavior using SECM in various applications, including water splitting, fuel cells, and MOBs. The FB mode of SECM is general tool for analyzing the surface characteristics of electrocatalysts, whereas G/C and RC modes are employed for comparison and to evaluate catalytic activity. This suggest that electrochemical imaging analysis based on SECM enables the differentiation of localized catalytic activity attributed to factors such as grain boundaries, phases, orientations, and compositional elements within energy materials. Moreover, the rapid screening techniques conducted within a consistent measurement environment significantly contribute to the reasonable selection of catalytic materials, thereby enhancing the optimized performance. In the context of electrocatalytic reactions, it aids in understanding gas bubble nucleation and gas transport within PTLs. In LOB systems, SECM enables real-time observation of oxygen behavior during operation and the design of RMs to enhance the efficiency of the LOB. Additionally, the observation and detailed analysis of reaction intermediates, reaction sites, and rate constants in catalytic reactions provide insights into reaction mechanisms and kinetics. Therefore, SECM plays a crucial role in guiding the development of advanced energy devices by providing valuable insight into electrocatalysts and their reactions. For a comprehensive overview of SECM operations, the approaches mentioned in this review paper are summarized in Table 1 . To date, the remarkable progress in SECM has been explored in the field of energy conversion and storage systems. Nevertheless, several challenges persist in obtaining meaningful electrochemical data using SECM. To begin with, reliable and reproducible measurements are hindered by the probe tip contamination and material transformation of the substrate surface during electrochemical reactions. Electrode contamination often arises as a result of phase transitions occurring during electrochemical reactions. Catalyst reactions, such as HER and OER, encompass gas generation reactions, whereas battery systems may lead to the formation of solid-state products. This may include the deposition of solid-state products, like passivation layers on electrode surfaces or the adsorption of gas products formed through the electrolyte decomposition. These products can adhere to the electrode, leading to interference and yielding distorted results that deviate from the actual electrode characteristics. These issues cause instability in the imaging process, resulting in poorly resolved images. Therefore, it is crucial to develop methodologies that minimize scanning time and establish hybrid systems capable of integrating diverse measurement methods to complement qualitative analysis. The second challenge involves the previous interpretation of complex reactions occurring within the diffusion layers between electrodes and the lack of established background knowledge regarding components of electrochemical cells (electrolyte, mediator, tip, applied potential, measurement mode, etc.) designed to simulate new energy systems. SECM, not being structurally identical to actual cells that function as energy systems, introduces various variables, such as electrode distance, resistance, and the diffusion of molecules within the solution. Therefore, a clear interpretation and in-depth understanding of these factors are necessary to extrapolate the results of SECM to real cells. Recent efforts have explored artificial intelligence-driven (AI-driven) automation for data processing as an alternative to elucidate the interrelation among these complex factors. However, this work is still in its early stages and requires more concerted efforts. The third task revolves around spatial resolution, with the diameter of SECM tips directly related to this aspect. The commonly used micrometer-sized tips lead to spatial resolutions in the sub-micrometer range. However, to effectively analyze the electrode components within energy systems through imaging with high spatial resolution, tip sizes in the range of several hundred to a few nanometers are required. Furthermore, for precise SECM data acquisition within the diffusion layer, measurements must be performed at scales where the distance between tip and substrate is smaller than the tip diameter. As tip sizes decrease, closer proximity to the substrate becomes necessary, requiring advanced technology for SECM analysis. Ongoing research, which integrates AFM with SECM, aims to minimize the tip size and the distance between the tip and electrode. Despite these efforts, practical constraints persist in achieving sufficient spatial resolution and simulating energy systems, presenting ongoing continued challenges in this technology. Thus, there is a need for the proposal of new concepts or novel ideas. Finally, there is the challenge of establishing an optimized measurement environment, especially when dealing with highly reactive materials such as lithium within the electrochemical cell. When analyzing systems involving highly reactive materials, it is crucial to create an ambient environment to suppress reactions with moisture or atmospheric constituents. While the primary approach involves setting up the system inside a glove box, this presents challenges related to cell operation, balance, and vibration control. It makes it challenging for smaller closed measurement systems to operate SECM under suitable conditions for each specific system. Therefore, there is a need for innovative concepts and developments in creating alternative and straightforward methods to establish conditions suitable for simulating energy systems. In conclusion, this review outlines the progression and application of SECM in the analysis of catalytic reactions within the energy conversion and storage field. The analytical methodology has undergone significant advancements, aiming to cultivate a thorough understanding of SECM-based electrocatalytic reactions. This comprehensive overview serves as a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners engaged in the realm of energy conversion and storage systems. Jihye Park (Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science) received her Ph.D. from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology in 2023. She joined the Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science as a post-doctoral researcher in 2023. Her research interests currently focus on next-generation energy storage systems, organic-based Li-ion batteries, and anode-free Li-ion batteries. Jong Hwan Lim (Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science) received his M.S. from Sungkyunkwan University in 2022. He joined the Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science as an intern in 2023. His research interests currently focus on material synthesis for anode-free batteries and the analysis of localized properties using SECM. His recent ongoing research includes the performance evaluation of electrode materials for batteries in an inert environment. Jin-Hyuk Kang (Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science) received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology in 2023. He joined the Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science as a post-doctoral researcher in 2023. His research interests currently focus on electrochemistry, electrochemical measurement, and next-generation energy storage systems, including alkaline metal–air batteries and Li-metal batteries. JiHeon Lim (Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science, and Seoul National University) received his M. S. from the Sogang University in 2019. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Seoul National Unversity. His research interests currently focus on the material synthesis for the catalyst of water splitting electrochemical. His recent ongoing research involves exploring technologies for producing clean, sustainable hydrogen gas using anion exchange membranes (AEM). Ho Won Jang (Seoul National University) is a full professor in Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Seoul National University. He earned his Ph.D. from the Department of Materials Science and Engineering of Pohang University of Science and Technology in 2004. He worked as a research associate at University of Madison-Wisconsin from 2006 to 2009. Before he joined Seoul National University in 2012, he worked at Korea Institute of Science and Technology as a senior research scientist. He is a member of Young Korean Academy of Science and Technology. His research interests include materials synthesis and device fabrication for solar fuel generation, chemical sensing, nonvolatile data storage, neuromorphic computing, plasmonics, ferroelectronics, and metal-insulator transition. Hosun Shin (Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science) received his Ph.D. from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology in 2011. He joined the Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science as a senior researcher in 2016 and was subsequently promoted to principal researcher in 2018. Dr. Shin currently holds positions as adjunct professor at UST (University of Science and Technology) and YU-KRISS (Yonsei University-KRISS) and is recognized for his expertise in the evaluation of thermal properties of semiconductor materials and data collection for artificial intelligence applications. Sun Hwa Park (Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science) received her Ph.D. from the University of Science and Technology in 2013. She joined the Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science as a senior research scientist in 2014 and worked at the University of California at Riverside as a visiting scholar in 2018. She is currently a principal research scientist and also holds an associate professor position in the Department of Applied Measurement Science at the University of Science and Technology. Her research interests currently focus on the synthesis of nanoengineered materials based on electrochemistry and the application of these materials in a variety of fields including electrocatalysis, energy storage systems and sensors. Her recent ongoing research includes the development of reliable electrochemical measurement and evaluation techniques related to water electrolysis system and lithium-ion batteries.

coredata.dc:description: To address climate change and promote environmental sustainability, electrochemical energy conversion and storage systems emerge as promising alternative to fossil fuels, catering to the escalating demand for energy. Achieving optimal energy efficiency and cost competitiveness in these systems requires the strategic design of electrocatalysts, coupled with a thorough comprehension of the underlying mechanisms and degradation behavior occurring during the electrocatalysis processes. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), an analytical technique for studying surface electrochemically, stands out as a powerful tool offering electrochemical insights. It possesses remarkable spatiotemporal resolution, enabling the visualization of the localized electrochemical activity and surface topography. This review compiles crucial research findings and recent breakthroughs in electrocatalytic processes utilizing the SECM methodology, specifically focusing on applications in electrolysis, fuel cells, and metal–oxygen batteries within the realm of energy conversion and storage systems. Commencing with an overview of each energy system, the review introduces the fundamental principles of SECM, and aiming to provide new perspectives and broadening the scope of applied research by describing the major research categories within SECM.
